qas.question: Who worked on the five Platonic solids?
Who measured the circumference of the Earth?
Who was the Father of Geomtery?

context: Hellenistic Geometers such as Archimedes (c. 287 – <a0_0>212 BC<a0_0/>), Apollonius of Perga (c. 262 – c. 190 BC), and Euclid (c. <a1_0>325<a1_0/> – 265 BC), whose Elements became the most important textbook in mathematics until the 19th century, built upon the work of the Hellenic era Pythagoreans. <a2_0>Euclid<a2_0/> developed proofs for the Pythagorean Theorem, for the infinitude of primes, and worked on the ﬁve Platonic solids. <a3_0>Eratosthenes<a3_0/> used his knowledge of geometry to measure the circumference of the Earth. His calculation was remarkably accurate. He was also the first to calculate the tilt of the Earth's axis (again with remarkable accuracy). Additionally, he may have accurately calculated the distance from the Earth to the Sun and invented the leap day. Known as the "Father of Geography ", <a4_0>Eratosthenes<a4_0/> also created the first map of the world incorporating parallels and meridians, based on the available geographical knowledge of the era.
